newsitem.title: UK: Just over half of Britons oppose EMU - poll.
newsitem.headline: Just over half of Britons oppose EMU - poll.

text.p: Just over half of all Britons tend to oppose a single European currency, according to an opinion poll published on Monday.
The Gallup poll conducted for the European Movement, a pro-European Union pressure group, showed 52 percent of those questioned tended to oppose the idea, while 41 percent tended to support it.
But it showed that two-thirds of the sample were open to persuasion about the advantages and disadvantages of British participation in EMU in 1999.
"The poll blows the single currency debate wide open," said Labour MP Giles Radice, the chairman of the European Movement.
"Many people will be surprised that three-quarters of the British people are either open to persuasion that Britain should join the single currency or are already in favour."
The poll showed that only 22 percent of Britons now think Britain should rule out joining EMU in the first wave, down from 36 percent in a similar poll conducted in August last year.
